article.headline: Trump White House accedes to FDAâs new vaccine safety guidelines
article.body: FDA Commissioner Stephen Hahn speaks at the briefing-room podium in August as President Donald Trump looks on. Saul Loeb/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images The White House endorsed the U.S. Food and Drug Administrationâs plans for assessing whether a COVID-19 vaccine should be given widely, casting aside objections to requirements that would likely mean a shot wonât be cleared until after Election Day, people familiar with the matter said. The FDA promptly issued the guidelines on Tuesday afternoon, saying it hopes the release âhelps the public understand our science-based decision-making process that assures vaccine quality, safety and efficacy for any vaccine that is authorized or approved.â See: Here are the FDAâs COVID-19 vaccine guidelines that the White House opposed Donât miss: Trump on FDAâs plan to pause vaccine clearance long enough to track trial participants: âThat sounds like a political moveâ The White House didnât immediately respond to a request for comment.
